A4.text: the city-states of ancient Greece (the poleis such as Athens, Sparta, Thebes, and Corinth)

A5.text: Athens could not be a polis without the Athenians.

A6.text: Lacedaemon had neither a city nor an acropolis, but all the historiographers referred to it as a polis.

A7.text: map and table of classical and archaic poleis

A8.text: list of personae from the fragments

A9.text: Sparta began to build a series of alliances, the Peloponnesian League, with cities including Corinth, Elis, and Megara, isolating Messenia and reinforcing Sparta's position against Argos, the other major power in the Peloponnese.

A10.text: Some city-states within Greece formed themselves into two major leagues; the Achaean League (including Corinth and Argos) and the Aetolian League.

A11.text: Athens was a centre for democracy, the arts, education and philosophy, and was highly influential throughout the European continent, particularly in Ancient Rome.

A12.text: Sparta was one of the most powerful city-states in ancient Greece.

A13.text: In antiquity, the state was known as Lacedaemon, while 'Sparta' referred to its capital, a group of villages in the valley of the Evrotas River in Laconia, in southeastern Peloponnese.

A14.text: Thebes' victory over Sparta at the Battle of Leuctra in 371 BC ended Spartan hegemony and freed Messenia from Spartan rule.

A15.text: Thebes was the largest city of the ancient region of Boeotia and was the leader of the Boeotian confederacy.

A16.text: Thebes was a major rival of ancient Athens, and sided with the Persians during the 480 BC invasion under Xerxes I.

A19.text: Athens was not the only polis in Ancient Greece that instituted a democratic resume.

A20.text: Athens and Sparta led several states to war with Macedonia
